document_title: Stage 3 breast cancer: Treatment methods and prognosis
subsection_name: ung-thu-vu-giai-doan-3.json_5_Follow-up care after treatment for stage III breast cancer
subsection_content:
After completing treatment, patients need to be followed for at least 5 years by oncologists. The follow-up schedule is usually every 3-4 months for the first 2-3 years, then every 4-6 months for the next 2-3 years. This follow-up schedule is not fixed for all patients, but can be adjusted depending on the risk level and health factors of each patient. During this time, patients with indications for supportive endocrine therapy (ER PR positive endocrine receptor) continue to maintain medication use.
Paraclinical examinations during the follow-up period (blood tests, breast ultrasound, mammography, whole body bone mineral density measurement, gynecological examination, chest X-ray, CT or PET-CT...) may be performed. will be prescribed differently for each patient, depending on factors such as age, disease stage, health status, menopause, breast cancer treatments that have been and are being performed...
For example: Patients who have breast conservation surgery and breast radiation therapy should have a screening mammogram every year, starting 6-12 months after the end of radiation therapy. In case patients receive supportive treatment with Tamoxifen, they should have a gynecological examination at least once a year.
For patients who have completed treatment, it is necessary to monitor their health to detect unusual signs and symptoms early. When experiencing any concerns, patients should go to the hospital as soon as possible.
Patients need a mammogram or other paraclinical examination methods if the doctor suspects stage III breast cancer has recurred.
For stage III breast cancer, although the rate of local recurrence and metastasis is high, the disease can still be controlled with individualized and specialized treatment regimens, plus cooperation. Patient initiative will lead to better treatment results. Because of this, Doctor II Tran Thi Thien Huong advises that breast cancer patients should go to reputable hospitals with a team of skilled and experienced experts and doctors; where there is modern equipment; There is coordination between Oncology, Endocrinology, Nutrition, etc. to consult, develop the most optimal treatment regimen, reduce complications, improve treatment effectiveness and predict better survival. .
